Award.AwardTitle: Dispersion-engineered membrane reflectors for reconfigurable dual-directional emission membrane lasers on silicon

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: This program is to investigate Fano resonance principles and dispersion engineering approaches in photonic crystal cavities, for reconfigurable dual-directional emission (vertical and in-plane) membrane reflector VCSELs on Si.

Intellectual Merit: The research will lead to the understanding of the fundamental Fano resonance physical characteristics and applications towards novel nanophotonic light sources with unique emission properties, as well as vertical-cavity edge-emitting lasers (VCEELs). Taking advantage of the unique modal characteristics and dispersion engineering capabilities in Fano resonance photonic crystal slabs, one of the Fano resonance Si-based membrane reflectors will be modified and designed to facilitate light coupling into in-plane waveguides, utilizing relatively large field concentration inside the Si-MR region.

Broader Impacts: The investigations of Fano resonance principles, coupled with various photonic crystal cavity designs, can impact a wide range of active and passive photonic device applications, such as lasers, detectors, modulators, couplers, and beam routing structures, etc. The reconfigurable dual-directional emission of ultra-compact lasers is highly desirable for a wide range of applications for both vertically and in-plane integrated photonics, as well as laser beam-steering and ranging systems. The success of the development of economical yet reliable lasers on Si will permit monolithic integration of sensing, spectroscopy, signal processing and computing all on a single chip. The education plan focuses on a few major activities, including interdisciplinary research and education, curriculum development on optoelectronics and green photonics, efforts to recruit underrepresented students in this research, and collaborations with national labs and industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project is to investigate Fano resonance principles and dispersion engineering approaches in photonic crystal (PC) cavities, for reconfigurable dual-directional emission (vertical and in-plane) membrane reflector VCSELs (MR-VCSELs) on Si. The basic MR-VCSEL on Si structure consists of transfer printed high quality InGaAsP quantum well (QW) active region (including cladding layers), sandwiched in between two single layer Fano resonance photonic crystal Si membrane reflectors (Si-MRs). Taking advantage of the unique modal characteristics and dispersion engineering capabilities in Fano resonance photonic crystal slabs, one of the Fano resonance Si-MRs will be modified and designed to facilitate light coupling into in-plane waveguide, utilizing relatively large field concentration inside the Si-MR region.

We have carried out the proposed research tasks as listed in the proposal. Specifically, we have made the following major achievements:

  1. Demonstration of 2D PC surface emitting lasers at low temperatures;  
  2. Room Temperature Photonic Crystal Bandedge Membrane Lasers on SOI Substrates;
  3. Photonic Crystal Bandedge Membrane Lasers on Bulk Silicon Substrates;
  4. Investigation of Thermal Performance on Photonic Crystal Bandedge Membrane Lasers on Bulk Silicon Substrates;
  5. Lateral Size Scaling of Photonic Crystal Surface-Emitting Lasers on Si;
  6. Development of Electrical injection for Photonic Crystal Bandedge Membrane Lasers with Buried Tunnel Junction;
  7. Demonstration of transferred QW on 2D photonic crystal (PC) membrane reflector (MR)-Couplers;
  8. Development of transferred 1D grating Coupler on Room Temperature Photonic Crystal Bandedge Membrane Lasers with Surface and In-Plane Dual-Emissions;
  9. Light emission with transfer printed silicon nanomembranes as hole injection layer.  

 One PhD was supported with this project and graduated. and graduated. Partial support was given for a few other students.

The project results in a total of 42 publications, including 1 book chapter; 11 journal publications; 20 invited conference talks; 10 contributed conference papers.
